New Records: Anthony Volpe became the first player in World Series history to log four RBIs and two steals in a single game.
Freddie Freeman became the first player to hit a home run in four consecutive World Series games (dating back to 2021 with the Braves).
Key Match Events: Anthony Volpe hit a go-ahead grand slam in the third inning to give the Yankees a 5-2 lead.
The Dodgers tied the game in the bottom of the ninth inning on a replay-activated double play, but the Yankees scored twice more in the eighth and ninth innings to secure the win.
Freddie Freeman hit a leadoff home run in the first inning to set the tone for the Dodgers.
Pre-Game Insights: The Yankees were trailing 3-0 in the World Series but managed to avoid a sweep, marking the first time since 1976.
The Dodgers relied heavily on their bullpen, with six relievers pitching in the game, but the Yankees' offense adjusted effectively.
Post-Match Reflections: Yankees manager Aaron Boone praised Volpe's performance, calling it a 'top blow off Yankee Stadium in a World Series game.'
Dodgers manager Dave Roberts acknowledged the Yankees' resilience and the bullpen's performance but expressed frustration with the outcome.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game saw a mix of offensive fireworks, including multiple home runs and a significant baserunning play by Anthony Volpe.
The Yankees' bullpen performed well, including key outs against Shohei Ohtani and Mookie Betts.
Others: The game marked the Yankees' first World Series Game 5 since 1970, showing their ability to rally from a 3-0 deficit.
